Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Understanding Emergent Responses and Decision-making under the Threat of Zika

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports Rapid Response Research. The researcher, anthropologist Dr. Lucia Guerra-Reyes of Indiana University, will collect data on existing community perspectives on reproductive decision-making in the context of imminent threat from a disease with severe reproductive consequences. This is an unusual opportunity. Social scientists often study how reproductive decisions are made at the individual and family levels when people learn of the potential of a genetic disease. But what happens when it is an infectious disease and the whole community and its future progeny are affected? Such a significant threat will be particularly illuminating for understanding disease-related decision making. Knowing how people respond to disease threat is critical for developing effective public health policy and effective messaging. But it is also important for tracking how people's behaviors affect the pathways through which the disease itself evolves and is transmitted. In addition, if the disease emerges as expected, collecting data now will provide a baseline that will permit a more complete characterization of emergent responses to disease threat.

The research will be carried out in Belem, Peru, an Amazonian region where the Zika virus is expected but has not yet arrived. The region has long been home to mosquito-borne diseases, including the dengue virus, which is carried by the same mosquito vector (Aedes aegypti) that carries Zika virus. Aedes egypti is common throughout the world, including the United States. The large mosquito population, the history of endemic dengue virus, and borders with already affected countries mean Belem community members are aware of the danger of disease, but have not yet had time to develop local responses. The researcher and her Peruvian collaborators will interview key informants (health officials, clinic workers, local leaders); carry out two focus groups (men and women); and conduct in-depth, semi-structured informant interviews with local men and women reached through clinics and by referral. The study of existing community perspectives on reproductive decision-making will allow future follow-up research in the event of Zika spread. Research findings will be of use to policy makers wherever Zika occurs and will also contribute to developing new theory about the interface between culture and biology. Funding this research also supports an international research collaboration of the sort that is critical in a world where disease outbreaks do not recognize national borders.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study took place as Zika virus infection was spreading rapidly throughout the Americas. When the study was conceived Zika was not yet a widespread epidemic in Peru, but it was imminent. We sought to understand existing cultural patterns for reproductive decision-making in Iquitos, a Peruvian city that was likely to suffer from Zika infection in the near future.  In this context, we hypothesized that understanding how men and women in unions made reproductive decisions, would allow us to better understand the likelihood of Zika infection risk in this population; and to assess pathways for effective prevention strategies. Zika viral spread began while data collection was ongoing, allowing us to register and analyze emergent public health responses, including an assessment of the role of health providers, and community reaction to early communication materials.

The study was conducted in a semi-rural area on the outskirts of the city of Iquitos, a neighborhood known as Moronacocha. We conducted focus groups (3) and in-depth interviews with community women (28) and men (21). Additionally conducting in-depth interviews with health personnel (6) in charge of Zika response at the neighborhood clinic and its subsidiary health posts. In addition to data collected in Iquitos the study also included interviews with the two people managing the Peruvian Zika response at  the national level.

Our findings in terms of reproductive decision-making contributed a novel understanding of how reproductive decision-making happens in practice. We have highlighted the crucial, yet seldom explored, role of men in reproductive decisions. We found that existing gendered dynamics of contraceptive negotiation result in increased risk for Zika virus infection and attendant child development consequences. While most contraceptive communication and information of Zika was only directed at girls and women, they have limited power to negotiate contraception and condom use. A cultural pattern of equating discussions of sexual issues as indication of female promiscuity, and equating condom use with risky behaviors, persisted across our community sample. These patterns rendered many of the initial Iquitos Zika emergency responses infective. For example, calling on the community to restrict pregnancy, and for pregnant women to use condoms in their committed relationships, were met with little action from the community.

This study increased knowledge of this novel disease and the social responses to it. Community members interviewed as the epidemic began in Iquitos demonstrated very low levels of knowledge of the signs and symptoms of Zika virus infection. Likening it with Dengue, they assumed that it had the same symptoms and prognosis. They were unaware of any non-mosquito form of transmission, and likewise did not know about possible fetal effects. Similarly health providers were unsure of what or how much to share with their patients. Several were doubtful of sexual transmission of Zika and of Zika virus as the causative agent of fetal brain impairment and microcephaly.

As a result of this study the researcher has established a fruitful international collaboration with a peer researcher at the Cayetano Heredia Peruvian University, which has resulted in a collaborative project funded through the Pan American Health Organization to assess similar issues in a different Peruvian region.

The study results have been presented in five peer reviewed conferences in anthropology, public health, and Latin American studies. Two manuscripts have resulted from the research, one is currently under review and the other in late stages of preparation.

This study had broad impacts beyond the researcher. A preliminary report with the results of our study was widely shared with local health authorities and participating clinic providers. Recommendations were made to local officials to purposefully include men in Zika messaging dissemination, in addition to highlighting non-mosquito forms of transmission and condom use as a method of prevention. Some changes in messaging during the later increase in Zika infections in Iquitos, indicate that these recommendations may have been of use to local authorities. Additionally results were shared with the World Health Organization group working on Zika emergency response through contacts from the Society for Medical Anthropology Zika group.
